sentences.sentence: Foreign relations Australia's failure to understand its influence with America is hindering its ability to shape global events.The world spends more time thinking about the United States than the United States spends thinking about the world.
Yet inside America, US leaders deeply respect Australia as a nation of substance.Australia's opinions, and more importantly its actions, are influential inside the world's most powerful nation.

Why else would America share its nuclear secrets with Australia?But ordinary Aussies struggle to see themselves that way.Australia's national pathology has always been anchored around a fear of abandonment - by the British Empire, by the United States, by the free world - and a bristling resentment for being made to feel like that.Australia's failure to understand its own influence is hindering its ability to shape global events.
Put simply, Australia's cultural cringe is directly undermining its national security.The response to Joe Biden's cancellation of his planned visit is a case in point.

The reaction revealed more about our own insecurities than it did about the US political dysfunction that caused the trip to be canned.But we needn't be so self-conscious or unsure of our relevance.Australia is a member of, or has an invitation to, all of the coolest clubs in international diplomacy: AUKUS, the Quad, Five Eyes, NATO, G7, G20.
You name it, we're there.But having a seat at the big table comes with obligations.And it's not clear Australians are entirely ready for the responsibility that comes with great influence.

Ever since prime minister John Curtin declared in the shadow of Japanese domination in 1941 that "Australia looks to America", Australians have debated what our principal ally expects in return for its safety guarantee.Sceptics contend that in order to maintain favour with its Big Brother protector, Australia is obliged to follow the US into any military folly, no matter how big or disastrous.Meanwhile, those nervous about Australia's geographic isolation believe the country must forever be earning its stripes to stay safe.So, rather than characterising the US-Australia alliance as an adult relationship of equals, Australia's strategic posture becomes a risible choice between being a helpless child or a bratty teenager.The latest debate to fall prey to this reductionism is the AUKUS pact.Depending on where you sit, the acquisition of US nuclear submarines is proof Australia has already signed on to fight in the coming war over Taiwan, or the final irrefutable sign that Uncle Sam will never leave our bedside.Reducing geopolitics to a heavyweight fight between the US and China misses the point entirely.

It makes Australia a hostage to events rather than a key participant with agency.The rather boring idea that Australia has taken the mature decision to defend its massive coastal approaches by borrowing the world's best undersea technology from our friends doesn't feature in this analysis.The same goes for that fact that, far from seeking to maintain American primacy for its own sake, it makes good strategic sense to keep the world's most powerful democracy heavily engaged in our region while we seek to convince Chinese leader Xi Jinping that war in East Asia is best avoided.Australia might not be the "indispensable nation" quite like the United States has been since World War II, but it is absolutely central to global security, and can facilitate the creation of a better world.We occupy a continent.
We are one of the world's oldest democracies.
We are a resources and energy superpower.

And we are located in the fulcrum of global competition, with access to the Pacific and Indian oceans.To paraphrase John F. Kennedy, perhaps it's time to ask not what the US can do for us, but what we can do for the US.
As it battles its internal orange demons and an ever-present isolationist streak, encouraging the US to be the best version of itself is more critical than ever.

In that, the power of Australia's lived leadership example will always be its greatest strength.In Washington, nobody asks whether Australia would sign on to a US-led effort to protect Taiwan from Chinese invasion.Instead, you'll likely get admiring questions about Australia's successful resistance of Chinese Communist Party trade coercion, the brave enacting of strong foreign interference and investment laws, and how Chinese technology giant Huawei was banned from building the national 5G network.Unlike Australia's much-debated role in a hypothetical war with China, these bold and independent policies are actively helping to safeguard the kind of world Australia wants.By acting in our own sovereign interests, Australia encouraged other nations - big and small - to step up and resist Xi's aggression in their own jurisdictions.

By going first, Australian leadership created a strength in numbers that a democratic nation of 25 million people must have to survive confidently in the long term.In an increasingly complex and dangerous world, nobody is coming to save Australia.
But independence doesn't mean standing alone or for nothing.

It means stepping up, making friends and courageously leading the way.Misha Zelinsky is a Fulbright Scholar, a former assistant national secretary of the Australian Workers' Union, and an expert associate at the National Security College.

documents.result_message: Our detector is moderately confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
documents.inputText: Foreign relations Australia's failure to understand its influence with America is hindering its ability to shape global events.The world spends more time thinking about the United States than the United States spends thinking about the world. Yet inside America, US leaders deeply respect Australia as a nation of substance.Australia's opinions, and more importantly its actions, are influential inside the world's most powerful nation. Why else would America share its nuclear secrets with Australia?But ordinary Aussies struggle to see themselves that way.Australia's national pathology has always been anchored around a fear of abandonment - by the British Empire, by the United States, by the free world - and a bristling resentment for being made to feel like that.Australia's failure to understand its own influence is hindering its ability to shape global events. Put simply, Australia's cultural cringe is directly undermining its national security.The response to Joe Biden's cancellation of his planned visit is a case in point. The reaction revealed more about our own insecurities than it did about the US political dysfunction that caused the trip to be canned.But we needn't be so self-conscious or unsure of our relevance.Australia is a member of, or has an invitation to, all of the coolest clubs in international diplomacy: AUKUS, the Quad, Five Eyes, NATO, G7, G20. You name it, we're there.But having a seat at the big table comes with obligations.And it's not clear Australians are entirely ready for the responsibility that comes with great influence. Ever since prime minister John Curtin declared in the shadow of Japanese domination in 1941 that "Australia looks to America", Australians have debated what our principal ally expects in return for its safety guarantee.Sceptics contend that in order to maintain favour with its Big Brother protector, Australia is obliged to follow the US into any military folly, no matter how big or disastrous.Meanwhile, those nervous about Australia's geographic isolation believe the country must forever be earning its stripes to stay safe.So, rather than characterising the US-Australia alliance as an adult relationship of equals, Australia's strategic posture becomes a risible choice between being a helpless child or a bratty teenager.The latest debate to fall prey to this reductionism is the AUKUS pact.Depending on where you sit, the acquisition of US nuclear submarines is proof Australia has already signed on to fight in the coming war over Taiwan, or the final irrefutable sign that Uncle Sam will never leave our bedside.Reducing geopolitics to a heavyweight fight between the US and China misses the point entirely. We are one of the world's oldest democracies. We are a major economy. We are a resources and energy superpower. And we are located in the fulcrum of global competition, with access to the Pacific and Indian oceans.To paraphrase John F. Kennedy, perhaps it's time to ask not what the US can do for us, but what we can do for the US. As it battles its internal orange demons and an ever-present isolationist streak, encouraging the US to be the best version of itself is more critical than ever. In that, the power of Australia's lived leadership example will always be its greatest strength.In Washington, nobody asks whether Australia would sign on to a US-led effort to protect Taiwan from Chinese invasion.Instead, you'll likely get admiring questions about Australia's successful resistance of Chinese Communist Party trade coercion, the brave enacting of strong foreign interference and investment laws, and how Chinese technology giant Huawei was banned from building the national 5G network.Unlike Australia's much-debated role in a hypothetical war with China, these bold and independent policies are actively helping to safeguard the kind of world Australia wants.By acting in our own sovereign interests, Australia encouraged other nations - big and small - to step up and resist Xi's aggression in their own jurisdictions. By going first, Australian leadership created a strength in numbers that a democratic nation of 25 million people must have to survive confidently in the long term.In an increasingly complex and dangerous world, nobody is coming to save Australia. But independence doesn't mean standing alone or for nothing. It means stepping up, making friends and courageously leading the way.Misha Zelinsky is a Fulbright Scholar, a former assistant national secretary of the Australian Workers' Union, and an expert associate at the National Security College.
